Award.AbstractNarration: This award is made as part of the FY 2016 Mathematical Sciences Postdoctoral Research Fellowships Program. Each of the fellowships supports a research and training project at a host institution in the mathematical sciences, including applications to other disciplines, under the mentorship of a sponsoring scientist. The title of the project for this fellowship to Irina Holmes is "Two-Weight Inequalities in Harmonic Analysis." The host institution for the fellowship is Washington University in St. Louis, and the sponsoring scientist is Brett Wick.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Intellectual Merit: The PI accomplished one of the main goals set out in the proposal, by proving a certain inequality for commutators in the multi-parameter setting. This work required a lot of new groundwork in this field to be laid out, and many of these results are still being used now by other mathematicians. Broadly speaking, multi-parameter analysis is much more difficult than "normal" analysis because of the geometry of squares versus that of rectangles. Think of a grid made of squares of the same size: in this case there is only one "parameter" to keep track of, namely the size of the side of the square, and the sqares cannot "overlap." Now replace squares with rectangles, and we have two "parameters" - length and width - and the rectangles can overlap in wild ways. 

The original proposal was written in the context of "classical" multi-parameter analysis, but during her last year at Michigan State University, the PI was part of an exciting new development in mathematics: dyadic trees and bi-trees. This is also a type of multi-parameter analysis: trees correspond to squares, and bi-trees correspond to rectangles. This is an exciting new area of mathematics which has many applications to complex analysis. While the difficulty comes from the same place as the classical situation, namely the different geometry of squares vs that of rectangles, this actually plays out differently in the case of trees and the impacts of these difficulties are new, and many are yet to be overcome. The PI, now a tenure-track professor at Texas A&M, is continuing research in this intriguing new area of mathematics.

Also during her stay at Michigan State, the PI learned the Bellman function method (one of the leading methods of proving inequalities in harmonic analysis) from one of the world experts who invented this method, Alexander Volberg. As a result, the PI is now also fluent in this method and will continue to explore its many applications yet to be discovered.

Broader Impacts: The PI worked on projects with four graduate students at MSU. These students are still in contact with the PI after her move to TAMU, and continue to see her as a resource for mathematics advice and professional advice. The PI has encouraged these four students to attend their first few conferences, helped them secure funding to attend these conferences, and helped them network and meet many senior mathematicians during these conferences. 

In March 2019, the PI was one of the three mini-course speakers at the conference ``Geometric and Harmonic Analysis 2019,'' aimed at graduate students in harmonic analysis. This conference was a great success in terms of popularizing the Bellman function method through the PI's mini-course lectures, as afterwards many young graduate students expressed interest in the method.

The PI has served as a mentor and role model for undergraduate students in STEM fields for many years, through her role as a teacher at Louisiana State University, Georgia Tech, Michigan State University, and now at Texas A&M. This holds especially true for young women who are beginning their journey in STEM fields as undergraduates -- the PI is still in contact with many previous female students from LSU, GT and MSU, some of whom are now in medical school, others in graduate school for different STEM related fields, and others finishing up their undergraduate degree. These students still seek the guidance and advice of the PI as they navigate certain obstacles in their professional lives, and credit the PI for serving as a strong role model to them as women in STEM fields. The PI is now building new such bridges at Texas A&M.

The PI has built many lasting relationships with graduate students and postdocs across the country, and has been especially helpful as a more senior yet still approachable resource to young women in math. The PI still has current working projects with two graduate students from Michigan State University.


Last Modified: 09/23/2020
Modified by: Irina Holmes
